titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Miscellaneous oversize photographs and lithographs V1974.030
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Patricia Glowinski
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-28T12:00-0500

physdesc.extent: 32 items housed in two folders and 1 oversize box.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Miscellaneous oversize photographs and lithographs, V1974.030, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction rights for the photographs have not been evaluated. For information on securing rights to publish or reproduce, please see the Brooklyn Historical Society Reproduction Rights Policy.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition for this collection are unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1974.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Item level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library. Please consult library staff for more information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Fully processed to the item level.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The accession file for this collection contains a list of names, presumably the names of some of the members of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church that are in the group photograph, taken circa 1925 (see: Object ID number V1974.30.10).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous oversize photographs and lithographs consists of 32 items, dating from circa 1870 to 1965, and measuring .5 linear feet. The majority of images are black-and-white, though there are several hand colored photographs. The collection is comprised of both photographic prints and lithographs. Subjects range from studio portraits, to views of buildings located in New York City, to views of parks and waterways in Brooklyn and New York City. The only cohesive element shared by all of the images is their size, though most are also related in that they are primarily depicting locations and people related to Brooklyn and New York City.
